org.writeforward.logger

Class MessageBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.writeforward.logger.MessageBuilder

  • public class MessageBuilder
extends java.lang.Object
    Use this class to build your message to be logged.

    For example:

     
 Log.message("There has been an error fetching a URL")
      .withException(ex)
      .withValue("URL", url)
      .error();
    Author:
    Matt

      This sets the hard-to-compute things like the origin of the request.

    • Constructor Detail

      • MessageBuilder

        public MessageBuilder(java.lang.String message)
        Start a Message object off right with an actual message.
        Parameters:
        message - A string that you want to log.

      • MessageBuilder

        public MessageBuilder(java.lang.String message,
                      java.time.Instant time,
                      java.lang.StackTraceElement[] stArr)
        This sets the hard-to-compute things like the origin of the request. Used if Log.isSlow is true.
        Parameters:
        message - A string that you want to log
        time - The time before the slow reflection operations to get the origin of this log.
        originClass - The file where this log originated.
        lineNumber - The line hwer this log originated.

    • Method Detail

      • withException

        public MessageBuilder withException(java.lang.Throwable exception)
        Have a throwable or exception you would like to log along side your message. Use this function to do so. You can only add one exception per log message.
        Parameters:
        exception - A throwable, exception, or error to be logged
        Returns:
        This message object modified with the exception.

      • withValue

        public MessageBuilder withValue(java.lang.String name,
                                java.lang.Object data)
        Add a variable value to be logged along with your message. toString() will be called on the data passed in, so for complex types it might be prudent to implement toString() so that it gives a meaningful message.
        Parameters:
        name - The name or meaning of the data passed in.
        data - The data you want to log
        Returns:
        This message object modified with the data.

      • withMarker

        public MessageBuilder withMarker(Marker marker)
        Add a SLF4J marker to this message. A marker is a type of tag used to filter messages. Markers are equal if their name is equal. If this method gets called more than once, additional markers will be added as children of the first marker.
        Parameters:
        marker -
        Returns:
        This message object modified with marker.
        See Also:
        org.slfj.Marker

      • withMarker

        public MessageBuilder withMarker(java.lang.String markerName)
        Add a SLF4J marker to this message. A marker is a type of tag used to filter messages. Markers are equal if their name is equal. If this method gets called more than once, additional markers will be added as children of the first marker.
        Parameters:
        marker -
        Returns:
        This message object modified with marker.
        See Also:
        org.slfj.Marker

      • withAdditionalMessage

        public MessageBuilder withAdditionalMessage(java.lang.String message)
        The message in Log.Debug(String message) not to your liking? No problem append an additional message here after a new line.
        Parameters:
        message - additional information to add
        Returns:
        This message object with a modified message.

      • withTimeStamp

        public MessageBuilder withTimeStamp(java.time.Instant time)
        Sets the time. If you don't need to set this don't bother. The time is set by default to when the log message is first created.
        Parameters:
        time - a java.time.Instant that contains the
        Returns:
        This message object with a modified timestamp.

      • withLogger

        public MessageBuilder withLogger(java.lang.String logger)
        What logger should we use when logging this message? The logger that will be used will be with the name of string passed to this method. Ignored if the logging framework does not support loggers.
        Parameters:
        logger - The exact name of the logger you want to use.
        Returns:
        This message with a non-null logger.

      • withLevel

        public void withLevel(Level l)
        Sets the log level. You can also use the trace(), debug(), info(), warn() and error() functions to set the level too.
        Parameters:
        l - The logging level to set the message to.

      • trace

        public void trace()
        Sets the log level to trace.

      • debug

        public void debug()
        Sets the log level to debug.

      • info

        public void info()
        Sets the log level to info.

      • warn

        public void warn()
        Sets the log level to warn.

      • error

        public void error()
        Sets the log level to error. Log4j's fatal() printing method is mapped to SLF4J's error() method with a FATAL marker. Add a new marker with the name FATAL to access the FATAL level if you are using Log4j.

      • fatal

        public void fatal()
        Sets the log level to fatal. This level, when dealing with SLF4J, will add a "FATAL" tag to the message, which will be turned back into a FATAL level when dealing with Log4j.
